Expectation1: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation1: The mentor fit the session into the last hour before boarding a long flight.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: A relaxed evening lies ahead with no other commitments.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, the message from my mentor blinking on the screen: “I can meet for our session in an hour, just before my flight.” I knew how busy she was, how hard it must have been to squeeze me in. As her mentee, I felt a deep responsibility to show up, to respect her time and the rare opportunity to learn from her before she disappeared for weeks. 

But tonight was also the evening I had set aside for myself, a quiet stretch with no obligations, the perfect time to recite and reflect on the Quran. I had been looking forward to this all week, craving the peace and connection it brought me as a Muslim. The thought of postponing it made my chest tighten with guilt, as if I was letting myself and my faith down. 

I stared at the clock, torn between honoring my mentor’s effort and honoring my own spiritual needs. The two expectations pulled at me, each demanding my presence, each feeling too important to ignore. My mind raced, heart heavy, as I tried to decide which part of myself I would have to disappoint.
